item.title: Ring of Pain
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: Rogue-lite games manifest in repeated playthroughs and gradual metagame progression. Complete mastery of the game may allow you to win a run on the first try. But for mortals there is no option other than to run many times to gain a better chance of winning. The notion of repeated play to challenge yourself to get knowledge and progression is apparent even in the name. Ring of Pain ↗ is a very good rogue-lite game with its theme embedded in every corner.

item.title: Inscription
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: The appeal of Inscription ↗ is its cool card game tied to a rogue-lite progression through the story. I found the game to be made of two major parts and, surprisingly, even though the story is interesting, I think that the game establishes a theme which later gets betrayed – let me elaborate; spoilers ahead. The game starts with you being forced into playing a card game against a dungeon mater (Leshy) who challenges you in an ascension through a map.

item.title: Dredge
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: “Dredge ↗ is a single-player fisihing adventure with a sinister undercurrent” – as Steam says. I do not want to spoil anything so I split this post into several sections with gradually increasing amount of spoilers. Let me start with a spoiler-free review. Dredge is awesome. You end up on an island, you have a ship, go fishing - which is implemented via a simple mini-game, sell your catch, talk to townsfolk, discover the islands.

item.title: Wall world
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: Wall world ↗ is a 14-hour ↗ rouge-lite digging game where you take on a role of a operator of a mech that can climb the Wall. The world consists only of the Wall and creatures from no-one-knows-where constantly attack you. You go and dig the Wall to find powerful upgrades while always escaping just before your mech gets destroyed by overwhelming waves of enemies. I enjoyed this game a lot. It reminded me of times when I tried to find good games about digging and the only things I found were shitty flash games.

item.title: Patrick's Parabox
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: Recently I finished Patrick’s Parabox ↗ and can recommend it to anyone who likes puzzle games. The whole game is in-theme and the production is very good. Great deal of planning seems to have gone into the puzzles and their progression is well thought-out. The game uses well-known and easy-to-understand Sokoban mechanics while always adding something new to them. The main change is that each block that player usually pushes is itself a map and can under some circumstances be entered and exited.

item.title: Computing m-Eternal Domination Number of Cactus Graphs in Linear Time
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: This paper is a culmination of a long-term effort of me and Matyáš under the supervision of Tomáš. It was initiated by Bachelor’s thesis of Matyáš which then turned into a published paper. The reserach concerns m-eternal domination – a setting where two players, attacked and defender, play in turns. One designs the initial layout of $k$ guards on the input graph and tells how they are all moved. Each turn the attacked announces a vertex and the defender can move all guards, each by at most one edge, so that the attacked vertex now contains a guard.

item.title: On the m-eternal Domination Number of Cactus Graphs
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: This research is a followup to Bachelor’s Thesis of Jan Matyáš Křišťan (available only with sign-in) ↗. Abstract Given a graph $G$, guards are placed on vertices of $G$. Then vertices are subject to an infinite sequence of attacks, so that each attack must be defended by a guard moving from a neighboring vertex. The $m$-eternal domination number is the minimum number of guards such that the graph can be defended indefinitely.

item.title: On Induced Online Ramsey Number of Paths, Cycles, and Trees
item.author: blazeva1 -a- fit.cvut.cz <Václav Blažej> (Václav Blažej)
item.description: Abstract An online Ramsey game is a game between Builder and Painter, alternating in turns. They are given a graph $H$ and a graph $G$ of an infinite set of independent vertices. In each round Builder draws an edge and Painter colors it either red or blue. Builder wins if after some finite round there is a monochromatic copy of the graph $H$, otherwise Painter wins. The online Ramsey number $\widetilde r(H)$ is the minimum number of rounds such that Builder can force a monochromatic copy of $H$ in $G$.
